article.headline: UCLA 85, Pepperdine 83
article.story: LOS ANGELES (AP) -- UCLA's kids were all right. Jordan Farmar scored a season-high 25 points and drove the lane for the go-ahead basket with 4.7 seconds left to give UCLA an 85-83 victory over Pepperdine on Saturday. Josh Shipp had 15 points and 12 rebounds starting for injured senior Dijon Thompson. Lorenzo Mata had seven points and 11 rebounds. Arron Afflalo scored 11 points. In all, the four freshmen scored 58 of UCLA's 85 points and grabbed 27 of the 41 rebounds. Farmar and Shipp combined to score the Bruins' last 11 points. "The four freshmen did a great job. This was a gutty win against a good team," UCLA coach Ben Howland said. "Jordan Farmar was very, very good, in transition, in penetration. Josh Shipp, I just can't explain how good he was." Alex Acker's 3-pointer to win bounced off the rim as time expired, snapping Pepperdine's seven-game winning streak that began after the Waves (7-2) lost their opener to East Carolina. Glen McGowan scored 24 points and Acker added 19 for the Waves, who snapped a 12-game losing streak against the Bruins in 2001 with an 85-78 upset at Pauley Pavilion in coach Steve Lavin's penultimate season. "We let them go down and score just about every time in the last 2½ minutes," Pepperdine coach Paul Westphal said. "They made the plays and we didn't." Such was Howland's confidence in the youngsters that he had four of them on the floor with the game in doubt. "We played aggressive, we were balanced and we were confident," Farmar said. Pepperdine was off to its best start in nearly 20 years and seeking its second straight victory over the Bruins (5-1) for the first time since the series began. But Farmar took over the game in the final 2:07, scoring nine of UCLA's final 11 points. He was fearless when the lane opened up in the closing seconds. "I heard coach screaming at the top of his lungs just to go, so I went," he said. "I thought McGowan was coming over to try to block the shot, so I put it up a little higher than usual, but he didn't come over all the way." Farmar's 25 points were the most by a UCLA freshman since Jason Kapono did it twice in the 1999-2000 season. "It was huge," he said about the victory. "I would've been very bitter if we'd lost the game." The Bruins started three freshmen, with Shipp joining regulars Farmar and Afflalo as the replacement for Thompson, who leads UCLA in scoring and rebounding. Shipp made a key steal inside, then scored on a drive to tie the game at 81 with 52 seconds left. "Josh is my roommate. He shows me every day," Farmar said. "I know exactly what he's capable of. It was just a matter of time." Acker missed a jumper, but Yakhouba Diawara tipped the ball in to give Pepperdine an 83-81 lead. "I got in front just in time to get the ball," Shipp said. "I try to play hard every night and when you play hard good things happen." Farmar made two free throws for an 83-all tie. Diawara lost the ball out of bounds with 9 seconds remaining before Farmar scored on the winning drive. "I wanted to call the timeout if we couldn't get it in," Westphal said. "I guess he thought he could get it in and we just couldn't connect." The Bruins survived a mistake-prone stretch midway through the second half, when Pepperdine gained its first lead and built a seven-point advantage. As good as Farmar was at the end, he showed he's a freshman. He tossed up an airball as the shot-clock expired and missed on a drive. Brian Morrison missed an open 3-pointer, then turned the ball over on a bounce pass in the lane. But Pepperdine was in foul trouble in the final 8 minutes and McGowan received a technical for hanging on the rim after a dunk. The Bruins rallied behind Shipp, who rebounded a teammate's miss and scored, then hit a 3-pointer to pull them within two. Center Michael Fey had a productive game, with 13 points and six rebounds, helping the Bruins dominate the boards, 41-23. Thompson reinjured his right shooting hand late in UCLA's loss to Boston College last Sunday and needed 13 stitches to close the cut in the webbing between his index and middle fingers. The original injury occurred during practice in October. Howland said he hopes Thompson can return in time for next Saturday's home game against Michigan. UCLA leads the series 15-4.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.
